title: Putting Performance in Relatable Terms
author: Ethan Gardner
summary: Improving web performance can be challenging because technical terms like milliseconds often don't resonate with non-technical stakeholders. To gain support, it's important to present performance improvements in relatable terms that highlight their impact on user experience and business outcomes. Using visual aids and aligning performance goals with organizational objectives can effectively communicate the value of performance work to different teams.

title: Your Perfectionism is Lying to You
author: Patrick Morgan
summary: Perfectionism can hold you back from creating and achieving your goals. Instead of striving for perfection, focus on completing your work and being prolific. Embrace the idea that creating more often can lead to growth and improvement in your skills.

title: The Shape of Runs to Come
author: Articles by Ryan Mulligan
summary: The author has recently returned to running on Sunday mornings after overcoming lower body issues. Listening to an album from their youth, "The Shape Of Punk To Come," energized their run and helped them exceed their goal. The nostalgic music made the experience exhilarating, reminding them of their younger self.

title: Introducing o(m)g:image
author: Jim Nielsen’s Blog
summary: Jim Nielsen created a digital game called “o(m)g:image” where players guess article titles based on social media share images. The game highlights the absurdity of needing a unique image for every web page, as many images often have little to do with the content. Nielsen believes that while social share images aim to attract clicks, they frequently end up being generic and unrelated to the articles themselves.

title: Understanding the main thread in the browser
author: Amrik Malhans
summary: The main thread in a browser is responsible for executing JavaScript, handling user interactions, and updating the Document Object Model (DOM). Although JavaScript is single-threaded by nature, it uses an Event Loop to manage asynchronous tasks without blocking. This design simplifies the process, avoiding complex issues like race conditions and ensuring smooth performance.

title: Will A.I. Eat The Browser?
author: Crazy Stupid Tech
summary: The author, Om Malik, reflects on the limitations of traditional web browsers as technology evolves towards immersive experiences like AR and AI. He argues that the browser must adapt to remain relevant in a future where information is increasingly personalized and accessed through various devices. The transition to a new browser model will be gradual but necessary to meet changing user needs and technology advancements.

title: I’m in the final third of my life
author: Derek Sivers
summary: Derek Sivers reflects on being in the final third of his life and feels inspired to act quickly. This urgency helps him focus on what truly matters and encourages him to share his thoughts more openly. He believes that sharing his perspective will allow a part of him to live on after he is gone.

title: Come and get me (both you and AI)
author: Derek Sivers
summary: Derek Sivers invites both humans and AIs to understand his thoughts and values through his personal website. He believes sharing our perspectives can help others remember, recreate, and improve upon them. Sivers sees his site as a lasting autobiography that enhances future decisions.

title: I love the contradiction of religions
author: Derek Sivers
summary: The author, Derek Sivers, finds the contradictions in religions fascinating. He shares how different friends have completely opposing beliefs, each convinced they are right. Sivers enjoys exploring these views without needing to find a resolution.

title: Your website is a restaurant
author: Boris Schapira
summary: Creating a website is like opening a restaurant, where careful planning and teamwork are essential for success. Just as restaurants refine their menus and service through practice runs and feedback, websites must also optimize the user experience and functionality. As the restaurant grows, the owners face new challenges in maintaining quality while expanding services and offerings.

title: Code shufflin’
author: Robin Rendle
summary: The author, Robin Rendle, feels he is not a true programmer but enjoys the freedom that coding offers. He prefers to hack together ideas rather than focus on perfecting code, finding joy in the progress made each day. Despite not being an engineer, he has a talent for spotting issues in code and appreciates the comfort of working in a large codebase.

title: The Evolution of Instant Web: What It Means for Performance Tooling
author: Ana Boneva
summary: Traditional website optimization techniques like caching and resource compression help improve speed, but they have limitations. The new Speculation Rules API enhances performance by allowing browsers to prefetch or prerender pages based on user behavior, leading to nearly instant navigation. Combining these approaches creates a smoother browsing experience with reduced delays and faster content loading.

title: I got the ADHD, too
author: daverupert.com
summary: The author shares their recent diagnosis of Adult ADHD and reflects on their experiences with it. They describe how they manage tasks and cope with overwhelm, emphasizing their unique brain needs. The author is trying a new medication to help improve focus and is optimistic about the journey ahead.

title: Beware the “Early Januaries” Content Pattern
author: jarango
summary: The "Early Januaries" pattern shows how people start strong in the new year but often lose interest quickly, leading to unfinished projects. This happens in content systems too, like Kindle's Popular Highlights, where most highlights come from the beginning of books. To improve this, readers should focus on later chapters, authors should provide value early, and designers should create systems that highlight important content throughout.

title: P&B: Erica Fustero
author: hello@manuelmoreale.com (Manuel Moreale)
summary: Erica Fustero, a multidisciplinary designer from Spain, shares her creative journey on her blog, ericafustero.com. She started blogging in 2007 and now posts about her illustrations, photography, and life's adventures. Erica emphasizes the importance of being true to oneself in the blogging process and enjoys connecting with others through her work.

title: SUX sells, but how to sell SUX?
author: Karlijn Lŕ¸ŁÂƒŕ¸˘ŕ¸–wik
summary: Karlijn Löwik reflects on her experiences promoting Sitespeed User Experience (SUX) in eCommerce, noting that many professionals lack a clear understanding of Core Web Vitals. She emphasizes the importance of making web performance topics accessible and engaging to inspire action across all organizational levels. Looking ahead, she advocates for a new metric, the CrUX score, to help business stakeholders understand user experience better.

title: Let's pause for a moment, I need time to think
author: Baldur Bjarnason's Notes on the Web
summary: The author is pausing their blog to reflect on its direction and purpose after years of success. They plan to take a break, which may last a few weeks or months, and will continue to share updates on the site without regular newsletters. The author is unsure about the future of the blog but hopes readers will stay engaged during this time.

title: How Undersea Cables Connect the Global Internet
author: Adactio: Links
summary: The undersea telecommunications cable connecting Tonga to the internet was damaged in a volcanic eruption, leaving the island nation cut off for three days. These cables, crucial for global communication, are often vulnerable to various hazards and require careful installation and maintenance. Many places, like Tonga, rely on a single cable, making them susceptible to outages that can disrupt their connection to the world.

title: Start at the end – talk summary
author: Hannah Smith
summary: Hannah Smith's talk emphasizes the importance of humanity and storytelling in achieving digital sustainability. She encourages incorporating imagination and play into our work to inspire positive change and outcomes. By focusing on the stories we tell, we can shape beliefs and foster a more sustainable future for the digital world.

title: The correct amount of ads is zero
author: hello@manuelmoreale.com (Manuel Moreale)
summary: The Verge has introduced a subscription model for their site, which includes full-text RSS feeds for subscribers. However, the author believes that there should be zero ads for paying subscribers. They argue that paying for content means users should not have to see ads or have their data sold to advertisers.

title: PLUGGING IN AND MAXING OUT: how data centres could drain Europe’s power supplies and threaten climate action
author: Victoria O May
summary: The rapid growth of data centres in Europe, driven by AI technologies, is causing a huge increase in power demand that could strain energy supplies and harm climate goals. If this demand is not met with additional renewable energy, it may lead to a rise in fossil fuel use, undermining efforts to decarbonize by 2035. Companies must prioritize sourcing new renewable energy to power data centres and reduce reliance on fossil fuels to stay on track for a sustainable future.

title: Attempting a Safari Move
author: Chris Coyier
summary: Chris Coyier shares his experience switching from Arc to Safari as his main web browser. He expresses frustration with Arc's shift towards ambitious AI features while feeling they have neglected the core product. While he finds some useful features in Safari, he misses certain functionalities from Arc that enhance his browsing experience.

title: PyMyFlySpy: track your flight using its headrest data
author: Robert Heaton | Blog
summary:
“Where are we daddy?” asked my five-year-old.
“We’ll land in about an hour,” I said.
“No I mean where are we? Are we flying over Italy yet?”
I wasn’t sure. Our flight was short and cheap and the seats didn’t have TV screens in the headrests. I looked around. I noticed a sticker encouraging me to connect to the in-flight wi-fi. That would do it, I thought. A site like FlightRadar would answer my little man’s question, down to the nearest few meters.
But unfortunately for him I’m the creator of PySkyWiFi (“completely free, unbelievably stupid wi-fi on long-haul flights”). Not paying for airplane internet is kind of my signature move. We’d need a different, offline strategy.

I had a think. When you connect to an airplane wi-fi network, you’re usually met with a payment page where you can purchase access to the internet. The page also usually gives you the same flight information that you’d find in the back of your headrest, like speed, direction, and estimated flight length. Perhaps it would have a map as well, I thought.
I pulled out my laptop, connected to the network, and loaded up the payment page. It did indeed show our wind speed, direction, and estimated time of arrival. But no map.
(It didn’t occur to me to screenshot the page so here’s an artist’s impression)

“Maybe the server that’s sending us this data is actually also sending us our location, but the web page isn’t displaying it,” I thought. I opened up the Chrome developer tools. I saw that my browser was making regular requests to a /info endpoint.

I clicked on one of the requests. This /info endpoint was indeed sending us a huge pile of data, including fields for ground_speed, wind_speed, and estimated_arrival_time. At the bottom of the response I noticed fields for latitude and longitude. My heart leapt. But then I looked closer. They were both null. Aerofoiled.
This looked like the end of the line. I was about to give up and tell my son that we were somewhere just north of Italy, probably…Europe ...

title: On blogging, substacking (?), and owning digital real estate
author: hello@manuelmoreale.com (Manuel Moreale)
summary: The author is critical of Substack, arguing that users do not truly own their content if they use a subdomain. He believes that Substack's business model encourages monetization of personal content, which harms genuine expression. The author advises people to have their own domain to maintain control over their digital presence.

title: Using Transformers.js for AI in the Browser
author: Raymond Camden (raymondcamden@gmail.com)
summary: The author discusses using Transformers.js to implement AI features directly in web browsers. It allows tasks like sentiment analysis and object detection, making it easy for developers to enhance user experiences. The author provides examples and demos, highlighting its practicality despite some performance considerations.

title: Reflections on Marriage
author: Melanie Sumner
summary: Melanie Sumner reflects on her experiences attending a cousin's wedding, highlighting the importance of personal connections and the realities of marriage. She critiques outdated views of women as possessions in marriage ceremonies and emphasizes the need for equitable partnerships. Ultimately, she encourages others to embrace their individual paths and reject societal norms about marriage.
